answers.answer: While many young people with Type 1 diabetes do go through rough transitions in their teen years, your son's behavior sounds like it is beyond that. Were the counselors he was seen by licensed mental health professionals? If so, I'm surprised that they didn't diagnose him with something else going on psychologically, which is what my gut is telling me.As a Type 1 diabetic (much older) I feel for your son and cannot even imagine how you must worry about him. On the other hand his behavior is unacceptable with or without diabetes and he is holding you emotionally hostage. That is no way to live. I will admit I am not a parent, so take my opinion for what it's worth. But you are not helping him and he is an adult who will not get help until he wants to. But that doesn't mean you have to put up with and finance it both with money and the extreme disruption to your peace of mind. I would tell him he either needs to get help or live on his own. But if you say that you need to mean it.

Thank you for your comment.  Yes, all three therapists were licensed.  He went to one four times and refused to go back.  He was in the mental ward for a two day stay after making threats and saw one there.  The third one he saw twice and refused to go back.She prescribed medication.  He doesn't have a drivers license because he refuses to pay 1/2 his insurance. (That has been a family rule for his older siblings.  We feel they need to have an investment in driving.)  He has a 6 week summer job but is blowing the money on computer games. He was gone all weekend again because we wanted to take him on vacation for four days.  He wants to have us turn the house over to him instead. Maybe we will survive until we can send him away to college in August.
I'm sorry it is so difficult for your family. Best of luck to you and your son.

question: My 18 year old type one diabetic son is both physically and verbally abusive and refuses to follow any rules.  He stays out all night without letting us know where he is.  He dares us to throw him out and has almost bankrupted us with his behaviors that have put him in the hospital.  He refuses to learn how to take care of his diabetes and will not let us do anything to help him.  he has been to several couselors and even hospitalized over his behavior.  They all say the same thing: he's unreasonable.  If he did not have the diabetes we would have kicked him out and let him find out what the real world is like.  What do we do with this one?  He refuses to see another counselor.Thanks,momofabusiveson
title: When is enough enough?
